thread.title: Gateshead EU Referendum results: Did your area vote Leave or Remain?
thread.title_full: Gateshead EU Referendum results: Did your area vote Leave or Remain?

author: Keiran Southern
title: Gateshead EU Referendum results: Did your area vote Leave or Remain?
text:
Voters across the borough sent out a resounding message, with a clear victory for Brexit Shares Get daily news by email 
Gateshead emphatically rejected the European Union in a dramatic night in the North East. 
Voters in the borough chose to leave by 58,529 votes against 44,492 with a turnout of 103,007, or 70.6%. 
Gateshead joined North Tyneside, Durham, Gateshead, and Sunderland in voting for Brexit while Newcastle voted in favour of Remain in the EU referendum. 
In dramatic scenes at Gateshead Leisure Centre , the result was read out to loud cheers from Brexit fans as stunned Remain supporters stared on in disbelief. 
Early in the night buoyant Remainers appeared confident before the tide turned and early results started to drip in in favour for Leave. 
By 1am it became clear Gateshead would follow the rest of the North East in rejecting the case for Remain. 
Blaydon MP Dave Anderson campaigned to remain in the EU, though predicted the region would vote to leave. 
He said: “I am surprised it’s not worse than what it was. People in the North East feel completely left behind and this is voters saying enough is enough. 
“People are desperate. All of us have to get our act together. Instead of blaming immigrants, we need to start putting money into the NHS and realise we need to pay more tax. 
“And in their campaign, they worked immigration to death.” 
Gateshead MP Ian Mearns also campaigned to stay inside the EU but saw his constituents reject his calls to back the union. 
He said: “I anticipated an out vote but not to that level. If we are asking what happened, first and foremost all of the faces we saw in the build-up were in favour of Brexit. I do not think people backing Remain had enough of a hearing. 
“In the North East, people are sick of austerity, they are sick of cuts and they have decided to stick two fingers up to David Cameron and George Osborne. 
“And we can not get away from it, people are worried about immigration.” 
Results after 0 of 382 areas declared Waiting for the first results Leave: 1,197 votes (50%) As it stands Britain is set to Remain in the EU
